34: root@one:~# We can see here the state of the two servers. Server one is a DRBD Primary, it also has the /dev/drbd0 drive mounted to /mnt^C
35: root@one:~# Notice the "ro:" part in the lower lines. ro stands for Role, and on the first server the order is Primary/Secondary, which means he is primary.^C
36: root@one:~# We are now going to isolate the two servers in order to simulate a failure scenario.^C
39: root@one:~# We can now see that server TWO has switched to Primary and /mnt was mounted. Server one did nothing, as in his view nothing's really changed except^C
40: root@one:~# that his slave/secondary server is now down. Server two however, in our case, would have also "stolen" the EIP. So now the EIP is on its interface.^C
41: root@one:~# let's see what happens when we resume the connection...^C
43: root@one:~# Server TWO immediately unmounted /mnt and assume a secondary role, but the "state" is still unclean as they're not connected...^C
46: root@one:~#
